text:
Is there a way to test the next 1.6 beta/rc release in gha CI before it’s released? I want to see how the release-1.6 branch works with some Pkg updates on other packages.
For instance, is there an action to build julia from a given branch/commit? I don’t mind if it takes a long time

Perhaps you could try downloading them from the link posted here: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/seeking-julia-1-6-binary-for-linux/52846/2|https://discourse.julialang.org/t/seeking-julia-1-6-binary-for-linux/52846/2>

attachments.title: Seeking julia 1.6 binary for linux
attachments.text: We actually do have “nightlies” for the release-1.6 branch. The URLs look like this: <https://julialangnightlies-s3.julialang.org/bin/linux/x64/1.6/julia-latest-linux64.tar.gz> As with any nightly builds, you should expect that the 1.6 nighties are unstable. @staticfloat @maleadt should we post the links for the 1.6 nightlies somewhere more visible?

text: It turns out that if the action is missing the `julia-build` step, no parallel precomp takes place because the package building in `Pkg.test` didn’t invoke `Pkg.precomp`. I’m working on adding precomp into `Pkg.test` by default, which should fix that

step, no parallel precomp takes place because the package building in
. I’m working on adding precomp into
by default, which should fix that

text: I just wanted to test it in the wild before the next proper beta2 etc.

elements.text: I just wanted to test it in the wild before the next proper beta2 etc.

elements.text: For instance, is there an action to build julia from a given branch/commit? I don’t mind if it takes a long time

text: oh cool, and cool!
Go to your PR, open up the buildbot `tester_*` job, click “build properties” and look at “download_url”

elements.text: Go to your PR, open up the buildbot
job, click “build properties” and look at “download_url”

text: It’ll give you something like:
`<https://s3.amazonaws.com/julialangnightlies/assert_pretesting/freebsd/x64/1.7/julia-4e6a3a4140-freebsd64.tar.gz>`
Cool, thanks!
nice

parameterizing that a bit, it’s:

```<https://s3.amazonaws.com/julialangnightlies/$BUILD_TYPE/$OS/$ARCH/$MAJOR.$MINOR/julia-$SHORTHASH-$OS$BITS.tar.gz>```

if you know all of those things beforehand, you can synthesize the url, but it’s a little tricky because things get moved around (e.g. if a build passes its tests, instead of it being in the `assert_pretesting` build type bucket, it’ll get moved to just `assert` to show that it’s passed its tests)

elements.text: if you know all of those things beforehand, you can synthesize the url, but it’s a little tricky because things get moved around (e.g. if a build passes its tests, instead of it being in the
build type bucket, it’ll get moved to just
to show that it’s passed its tests)

text: just to clarify my message a few up, I originally wrote `julia-runtest` but meant `setup-julia`

elements.text: just to clarify my message a few up, I originally wrote

text: I think this was discussed before (I think <@U7THT3TM3> might have suggested it?). The actual installation of Julia is pretty trivial, so for maintenance purposes having a separate action for it is better. Most of setup-julia is about figuring out the correct version to use, and where to download it from.

might have suggested it?). The actual installation of Julia is pretty trivial, so for maintenance purposes having a separate action for it is better. Most of setup-julia is about figuring out the correct version to use, and where to download it from.

elements.text: can you use actions in actions?

text: You can if you are making a "composite action"

elements.text: You can if you are making a "composite action"

text: Composite actions don't support calling other actions yet (there's a tracking issue for it somewhere)

elements.text: Composite actions don't support calling other actions yet (there's a tracking issue for it somewhere)

text: Some actions also come as a JS/TS package so you could kinda embed them

elements.text: Some actions also come as a JS/TS package so you could kinda embed them

text: But generally, no, you can't right now.
